relations.sentence: TGFß1 Cell Cycle Arrest Is Mediated by Inhibition of MCM Assembly in Rb-deficient Conditions Brook S. Nepon-Sixt and Mark G. Alexandrow Brook S. Nepon-Sixt PDF Abstract Transforming growth factor ß1 (TGFß1) is a potent inhibitor of cell growth that targets gene-regulatory events, but also inhibits the function of CDC45-MCM-GINS helicases (CMG; MCM, Mini-Chromosome Maintenance; GINS, Go-Ichi-Ni-San) through multiple mechanisms to achieve cell-cycle arrest.

relations.sentence: TGFß1 Cell Cycle Arrest Is Mediated by Inhibition of MCM Assembly in Rb-deficient Conditions Brook S. Nepon-Sixt and Mark G. Alexandrow Brook S. Nepon-Sixt PDF Abstract Transforming growth factor ß1 (TGFß1) is a potent inhibitor of cell growth that targets gene-regulatory events, but also inhibits the function of CDC45-MCM-GINS helicases (CMG; MCM, Mini-Chromosome Maintenance; GINS, Go-Ichi-Ni-San) through multiple mechanisms to achieve cell-cycle arrest.
Such arrest occurs due to inhibition of MCM hexamer assembly by TGFß1, which is not seen when Rb is present and MCM subunit expression is normally blocked by TGFß1.

relations.sentence: Accordingly, overexpression of CDT1 with an intact MCM-binding domain abrogates TGFß1 arrest and rescues MCM assembly.

relations.sentence: The ability of CDT1 to restore MCM assembly and allow S-phase entry indicates that, in the absence of Rb and other canonical mediators, TGFß1 relies on inhibition of Cyclin E-MCM7 and MCM assembly to achieve cell cycle arrest.

The ability of CDT1 to restore MCM assembly and allow S-phase entry indicates that, in the absence of Rb and other canonical mediators, TGFß1 relies on inhibition of Cyclin E-MCM7 and MCM assembly to achieve cell cycle arrest.

Implication: These results demonstrate that the MCM assembly process is a pivotal target of TGFß1 in eliciting cell cycle arrest, and provide evidence for a novel oncogenic role for CDT1 in abrogating TGFß1 inhibition of MCM assembly.
